Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Impact of the emerging engineering education research and innovation community

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
There is currently little understanding of how to assess and document the impact of discipline-based research on education practice. The goal of this project is to establish such a process and begin to document the impact of the engineering education research and innovation (EER&I) community. It specifically addresses two questions: 1) What is the local and broad impact of selected EER&I programs? 2) What are the best ways to characterize and document the impact of these EER&I programs? Over the last 20 years significant progress has been made in better understanding how to improve engineering education, much of which has been funded by NSF. However, incorporation of research results into practice has not kept pace with the research enterprise, largely because there is little understanding of how to measure that impact. This proposal aims to address this gap; doing so would lead to significant change in the practice of engineering education.

The specific goal of this project is to develop and test a process for documenting the impact of engineering education research. This process will be framed around the business canvas model from the NSF I-Corps L program. The work will proceed through three primary activities: document the emerging network of EER&I faculty and identify examples of impact; conduct a summit for EER&I leaders and change experts to develop a process for documenting impact; and pilot the process at the three collaborating institutions. The process will then be tested at additional institutions, including those that do not have engineering education research activities. The results of the project will be summarized in a report and presented at the ASEE Annual Conference. By developing a process for documenting and assessing impact, research results can be more effectively transferred into practices to improve the professional formation of engineers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching goal of this project was to develop a process for documenting the impact of Engineering Education Research and Innovation (EER&I), an emerging field with a growing number of degree programs as well as independent practitioners embedded in traditional disciplines.   A Summit involving 30 EER&I leaders was held at Purdue University in September 2018.  The result of the Summit was a list of metrics that can be used to characterize the impact of EER&I and a number of formats that could be used to document that impact.  In addition, some participants in the Summit on the Impact of EER&I agreed to pilot a process for documenting the impact of EER&I at their institutions.  Two institutions collaborating on this project, Purdue University and Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, have posted their documents on their websites.  One can be found at https://indd.adobe.com/view/c0c8ea3c-a5e7-491c-864a-5cd39aeb456b?_ga=2.136109426.257048383.1566447329-1383997685.1564975323 .  The results of the pilots were shared with other EER&I practitioners at a workshop held at the 2019 American Society for Engineering Education Annual Conference. The ~60 workshop participants had an opportunity to begin developing plans for documenting the impact of EER&I at their home institutions. 

 

Being able to document the impact of EER&I efforts will allow faculty and administrators to identify those initiatives that have a significant impact so that engineering educators in all disciplines can make better decisions about which practices to adopt in their classrooms. Those practices will, in turn, make engineering education more effective and more diverse, allowing a growing number of students from a wider range of backgrounds to successfully complete their engineering degrees and pursue careers that allow them to contribute to society.
